author: hell_pike
content: Guys does ethereum have a plan to actually finish development, where the code is actually done and the devs walk away?

author: hell_pike
content: Or is it just constantly going to be developed... I mean eventually dishonest actors may become involved in the development process. They will cash in on all the hard work of the current team and abuse ethereum for their own goals

author: hell_pike
content: Burn it out for 10 years until it's totally worthless

author: sky.cactus
content: There isn't a concrete plan, but what you describe is a well known and somewhat understood attack vector.

author: sky.cactus
content: One of the defenses is to have a development process that is somewhat vague and involves multiple teams and people.

author: sky.cactus
content: So an attacker can't take over just one thing and start forcing change.  However, this isn't a perfect protection and there are examples of it being defeated.

author: sky.cactus
content: A more long term solution is as you suggested, to calcify the protocol as Bitcoin has done.  However, timing that is tricky because once calcified you start to fall behind competitors that are continuing to advance/adapt.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we can succeed in getting a great rollup baselayer then we have the option of continuing to iterate on that while the base layer calcifies.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think people *want* the EIP process to be subjective, but in order to do that we need to have full time staff who are ethos aligned to deal with that subjectivity.  Sophistication is very low for the majority of tasks, but there are a handful of tasks that one one may consider sophisticated.
